channel.title: My (relatively complete) Updater
channel.description: My updater, yes. I decided to post it because I saw in pplsuqbawlz's updater post where he said that no one else is releasing anything. It's almost complete. It dumps "fields.cfg" once it is done, because my bot uses reflection as of last night. Thanks to pplsuqbawlz for the cache unpacker, and thanks VERY much to Ollie, since I pretty much ripped my camera hooks from his updater. If you use it in a bot of your making, you don't need to give me credit. Just don't claim it entirely as your own creation. Reuploaded what I *think* is the method injecting version.

item.title: My (relatively complete) Updater
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Zappacky:

If everybody followed these (including myself, I dont claim to be anywhere near perfect), the world would be a wonderful place.

  1. It is NOT acceptable. There are no exceptions.

  2. If there is a problem, it will become a big problem unless it is promptly fixed.

  3. Unless it is a typo or a memory lapse, it is a design flaw and the system design should be refined.
    3a. A simple patch is NOT an acceptable substitute.

  4. Reliability and speed should never be a compromise. If it becomes a compromise, see rule number 3.

  5. Smaller is not always better. It usually is, however, because large binaries tend to be slow and full of bugs. If a binary becomes too large, see rule number 3.

  6. If it crashes randomly once, but never does it again, see rule number 2.

  7. No problem is ever too small. If the problem is too small, reread this rule, then see rules 6 and 2.

  8. Errors happen 1000% more frequently and faster on client computers. If an error occurs every 10 runs on your computer, it will be completely unusable on a client computer. If it occurs less frequently than that, see rule number 7.

  9. Code is always better the second time it is written than the first, and better the third than the second, and so on. When you think it is perfect, see rule number 1.

  10. It has not been tested enough. Period.

These can be simplified into two golden rules.

  1. It is never ‘good enough’. Period.

  2. Reliability should never impact speed. A well designed system is both reliable and fast.

Which can be further simplified into the golden rule:

  1. If it’s slow or it crashes, IT’S WRONG.

Read full topic

item.title: My (relatively complete) Updater
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:31, topic:122649”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=172353.msg1612580#msg1612580 date=1184876918]
If statements without braces is a personal preference thing I do believe, I avoid braces any time I possibly can, because I think they make the code look messy. The second thing you mentioned annoyed me for about 10 seconds until I hit the ‘format code’ button in IDEA. You are probably right about the last thing, but I don’t believe I have ever used ‘final’ in my programs, perhaps it comes from removing all the 'final’s in the runescape deob.
[/quote]

The only topic that has started more wars than ‘code formatting’ is religion. As one moves up the code maturity ladder, one tends to care less about where people do and do not indent and more about content. I can’t really talk because when I was new, I whined/complained/flamed/threatened people about their code style.

That was a long time ago. Some interesting points I’ve learned in 10+ years of professional coding:

[ul][li]1. Everyone (allegedly) writes crappy code…[/li]
[li]2. Everyone (amazingly) can write everyone else’s code better…[/li][/ul]

Those familiar with the craft know what I’m talking about. No matter where you go, you will find that there are idiosyncrasies and bad practices that you will find irritating. No company is immune to it. After a while, you stop caring about being pedantic and start caring about trying to learn from others’ code.[/quote]

It still doesn’t excuse you for your pedantic bad coding. Bahaha, I’m kidding!

Read full topic

item.title: My (relatively complete) Updater
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I prefer textpad. I hardly bother with IDEA.

As for if statements without braces, yes it’s definitely a preference thing.

But something like this:

if (condition) doThis();

is less likely to be misread then this:

if (condition) doThis();

If you’re working in a team with several people making changes, then you can probably see the likely hood of someone doing something like this when making a quick change:

if (condition) doThis(); andThis();

The logic error there is that the person who added it thought the method would only be called when condition evaluates to true, and if you’re working on a reasonably large program then that bug is going to be a bitch to hunt down.

As for using the final keyword, it’s just a nice thing to do if you’re releasing code for others to continue working on. As I said above, you can work out the class hierarchy faster.

Read full topic

item.title: My (relatively complete) Updater
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I took a look at some of your classes. The way you program is generally a bit yucky, at least judging by the few classes I looked over.

Firstly, the if statements without braces. There’s a good chance for logic errors in a bigger program. You’re not doing yourself any favors by not enclosing the body of your if statements. If anything, it’s increasing the chances that a third party like myself might accidentally add a statement that we think will only be executed if the if statement condition evaluates to true. If you absolutely feel compelled to not use braces, then why not put the if statement’s body on the same line?

Secondly, you don’t space your methods out at all. It’s all just one big clump of text. Sure, it’s ok when you’re working alone; but I wouldn’t fancy working in a team with you if you wrote your classes like that.

Another little thing for me was overall readability when it comes to inheritance. You’re using inheritance, which is great. But you could enhance readability by using the ‘final’ keyword in your method declarations. I’m absolutely positive that your subclasses don’t override every single method in your superclass. Having said that, why not make your methods final if you aren’t going to override them? It allows someone like me to be sure one way or another, without digging through other classes to check.

Read full topic

item.title: My (relatively complete) Updater
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:17, topic:122649”]Ok, well I just did some programming in the grand canyon, here are the results.

I did a few things to Silver Lining’s updater:

  1. Now platform independent
  2. No need to log into runescape before updating (downloads runescape.jar, does not use a cache file)
  3. Loads transforms dynamically from a config file, and runs them, no more hardcoding methods (to do #3, I deleted Fields.java and put it in WorldController.java, seemed more logical that way)
  4. Restructured packages a bit, nothing major

New updater attached to post.[/quote]

Stop touching the computer and go have fun…

Read full topic

item.title: My (relatively complete) Updater
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

The non-abstractness is because, in my current ugly version, the “update()” methods are all static.
EDIT: In 464, the position and animation hooks in Entity broke. Here’s the fixed versions:

[code]package updater;

import org.apache.bcel.generic.ClassGen;
import org.apache.bcel.generic.SIPUSH;
import org.apache.bcel.generic.FieldInstruction;
import org.apache.bcel.classfile.Method;
import org.apache.bcel.classfile.Field;

public class Entity extends Transform{
public void update(){
ClassGen c = findEntity();
names.put(“entity”, c.getClassName());
names.put(“animable”, c.getSuperclassName());
loopAndHeight©;
anim©;
pos©;
message©;
}
private void loopAndHeight(ClassGen c){
InstrSearcher i = new InstrSearcher(c, c.containsMethod("", “()V”));
i.nextSIPUSH(-1000);
fieldId(“Entity.LoopCycleStatus”, (FieldInstruction)i.next(“putfield”), c.getConstantPool());
i.nextSIPUSH(200);
fieldId(“Entity.Height”, (FieldInstruction)i.next(“putfield”), c.getConstantPool());
}
private void anim(ClassGen c){
for(Method m : c.getMethods()){
if(!m.isStatic() && !m.getName().equals("")){
InstrSearcher i = new InstrSearcher(c, m);
if(i.next(“iconst_m1”) != null){
if(i.next(“iconst_m1”) != null){
if(i.next() instanceof FieldInstruction){
fieldId(“Entity.Animation”, (FieldInstruction)i.current(), c.getConstantPool());
return;
}
}
}
}
}
System.err.println(“Error hooking entity animation.”);
}
private void pos(ClassGen c){
for(Method m : c.getMethods()){
if(!m.isStatic() && !m.getName().equals("")){
InstrSearcher is = new InstrSearcher(c, m);
SIPUSH s = is.nextSIPUSH(128);
if(s != null){
is.next(“return”);
fieldId(“Entity.Y”, (FieldInstruction)is.prev(“putfield”), c.getConstantPool());
FieldInstruction smally = (FieldInstruction)is.prev(“getfield”);
if(smally.getSignature(c.getConstantPool()).equals(“I”))
smally = (FieldInstruction)is.prev(“getfield”);
FieldInstruction x = (FieldInstruction)is.prev(“putfield”);
FieldInstruction smallx = (FieldInstruction)is.prev(“getfield”);
if(smallx.getSignature(c.getConstantPool()).equals("[I")) smallx = (FieldInstruction)is.prev(“getfield”); fieldId(“Entity.X”, x, c.getConstantPool()); fieldId(“Entity.SmallX”, smallx, c.getConstantPool()); fieldId(“Entity.SmallY”, smally, c.getConstantPool()); return; } } } System.err.println(“Error hooking entity coordinates.”); } private void message(ClassGen c){ for(Field f : c.getFields()){ if(!f.isStatic() && f.getSignature().contains(";")){ fieldId(“Entity.Message”, c.getClassName(), f.getName()); return; } } } private ClassGen findEntity(){ for(ClassGen cg : classes.values()){ if(cg.isAbstract()){ Method m; if((m = cg.containsMethod("<init>","()V")) != null){ InstrSearcher i = new InstrSearcher(cg, m); int count = 0; SIPUSH val; while((val = i.nextSIPUSH()) != null){ int x = val.getValue().intValue(); if(x == -1000 || x == 200) count++; } if(count == 2) return cg; } } } System.err.println(“Error hooking entity class!”); return null; } } [/code]

Read full topic

item.title: My (relatively complete) Updater
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Very nice, and much more object oriented than ppl’s version. The only thing I would change is like KryptoN_ said, make the update() method abstract in Transform so it must be implemented, and then dynamically load all the transforms (either all from one file, or from a config file) and run each of them, instead of having them hardcoded. All in all excellent job, and thank you for contributing.

Read full topic
